channel.title: Need USB to PS/2 Adapter
channel.description: Do these exist? I haven't been able to find one that lets me connect a USB-only keyboard to a PS/2 port on a computer. It needs to be active, because this isn't a dual-mode keyboard that comes with those little wire-only adapters.

item.title: Need USB to PS/2 Adapter
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

I can only assume bad reviews because people will compare them to usb keyboards which have a longer range and are generally newer.

Read full topic

But, being a Mac, it doesn’t support PS/2 does it? Which defeats the whole purpose (I need PS/2 support).[/quote]

I’m an idiot, didn’t read post properly.

something like this?

item.title: Need USB to PS/2 Adapter
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“c|p, post:8, topic:429909”][quote author=mwiebelhaus link=topic=532591.msg3893196#msg3893196 date=1327084497]
They don’t exist as far as my knowledge goes mainly because they would have to charge over 10+ for something that is not needed much. You can probably use an arduino or an msp430 and write the code yourself, I don’t know anything about the protocol so I cant do it without researching it
[/quote]

Arduino is extreme overkill for this…

You could go with a very low-end PIC: 8-bit, some have USB support (so you wouldn’t have to do that part yourself).
These look perfect, and they’re extremely low power, though I’m not sure if you can buy them yet.[/quote]
I did write a PS/2 to USB type adapter using a Teensy++ I had here:

moparisthebest.com

moparisthebest.com

programming, irc, cars

And actually, I want to use the same thing because it supports hardware qwerty -> dvorak conversion, which is why I’m looking for a USB -> PS/2 adapter.

@Different keyboard, I’m open to that, but I haven’t found any like I need. I need a smaller one (usually without a number pad) that will fit in a briefcase/laptop bag, and I’d like it to be wireless like the one I just bought is. I haven’t been able to locate one like that which supports PS/2.

Read full topic

item.title: Need USB to PS/2 Adapter
item.dc:creator: @eczema3 eczema3
item.description:
@eczema3 wrote:

why dont you just get a new keyboard for $3 that either has a PS/2 port or a USB port that supports the PS/2 protocol?

Read full topic

item.title: Need USB to PS/2 Adapter
item.dc:creator: @Cheese_Police c|p
item.description:
@Cheese_Police wrote:

mwiebelhaus:

They don’t exist as far as my knowledge goes mainly because they would have to charge over 10+ for something that is not needed much. You can probably use an arduino or an msp430 and write the code yourself, I don’t know anything about the protocol so I cant do it without researching it

Arduino is extreme overkill for this…

You could go with a very low-end PIC: 8-bit, some have USB support (so you wouldn’t have to do that part yourself).
These look perfect, and they’re extremely low power, though I’m not sure if you can buy them yet.

Read full topic

item.title: Need USB to PS/2 Adapter

item.description:
@teh_spede wrote:

Just get a better keyboard…

Read full topic

item.title: Need USB to PS/2 Adapter
item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:5, topic:429909”][quote author=Teh Spede link=topic=532591.msg3892984#msg3892984 date=1327059612]

this?
[/quote]

No. This is a passive adapter that has no circuitry in it, it simply adapts the shape of the plug, and if the keyboard doesn’t support falling back to the PS/2 protocol (mine doesn’t) it won’t work.

Which is why I need an active adapter with some sort of microprocessor or other circuitry in it to convert the actual USB protocol into PS/2 protocol.

The same thing applies to mwiebelhaus’s link, any ideas?[/quote]

They don’t exist as far as my knowledge goes mainly because they would have to charge over 10+ for something that is not needed much. You can probably use an arduino or an msp430 and write the code yourself, I don’t know anything about the protocol so I cant do it without researching it

Read full topic

item.title: Need USB to PS/2 Adapter
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Teh Spede, post:2, topic:429909”]
this?[/quote]

No. This is a passive adapter that has no circuitry in it, it simply adapts the shape of the plug, and if the keyboard doesn’t support falling back to the PS/2 protocol (mine doesn’t) it won’t work.

Which is why I need an active adapter with some sort of microprocessor or other circuitry in it to convert the actual USB protocol into PS/2 protocol.

The same thing applies to mwiebelhaus’s link, any ideas?

Read full topic
